items.title: Change headers to enable CORS

I would like to set my headers to something like

```
server.setHeader('Access-Control-Allow-Origin', '*')
server.setHeader('Access-Control-Allow-Methods', '*')
```

but it doesn't seem this functionality is exposed anywhere. What can I do to set headers?

items.title: Asyncio NotImplemented Error with Python 3.8 and Windows
items.body:
As explained in tornadoweb/tornado#2608, the default behavior in Python 3.8 has changed and we get an error on Windows only:

```
>livereload site
[I 191026 22:40:22 server:296] Serving on http://127.0.0.1:35729
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\runpy.py", line 192, in _run_module_as_main
    return _run_code(code, main_globals, None,
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "C:\Program Files\Python38\Scripts\livereload.exe\__main__.py", line 7, in <module>
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\livereload\cli.py", line 60, in main
    server.serve(host=args.host, port=args.port, root=args.directory,
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\livereload\server.py", line 298, in serve
    self.application(
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\livereload\server.py", line 253, in application
    app.listen(port, address=host)
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\tornado\web.py", line 2112, in listen
    server.listen(port, address)
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\tornado\tcpserver.py", line 152, in listen
    self.add_sockets(sockets)
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\tornado\tcpserver.py", line 165, in add_sockets
    self._handlers[sock.fileno()] = add_accept_handler(
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\tornado\netutil.py", line 279, in add_accept_handler
    io_loop.add_handler(sock, accept_handler, IOLoop.READ)
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\site-packages\tornado\platform\asyncio.py", line 99, in add_handler
    self.asyncio_loop.add_reader(fd, self._handle_events, fd, IOLoop.READ)
  File "c:\program files\python38\lib\asyncio\events.py", line 501, in add_reader
    raise NotImplementedError
NotImplementedError
```

It appears that Tornado is not going to override the default themselves, but instead expect applications using Tornado to override the default. In other words, Tornado expects Python-Livereload to set this itself.

Of course users of Python-Livereload who are calling the lib programmatically through Python code can just do the override themselves. However, anyone using the command line tool will need Python-Livereload to address this for them. Therefore, my question is: will Python-Livereload be addressing this for all users or only the command line tool?

items.title: Doesn't detect file deletion on macOS/Windows
items.body:
I was hoping to use this as a replacement for Pelican's development server, which has an option to automatically regenerate content when a file is created, updated, or deleted, but doesn't refresh the browser. I followed an [existing example](https://merlijn.vandeen.nl/2015/pelican-livereload.html) to get it going, but was surprised that files deleted from a watched directory/glob don't trigger a reload.

Looking through [watcher.py](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/master/livereload/watcher.py), it looks like this might work on Linux via `INotifyWatcher` and `pyinotify`. However, it seems like the base `Watcher` class used macOS/Windows walks the glob/directory tree looking for changes to files based on modification time, with no check for files that no longer exist.

items.title: Release the latest version on PyPi
items.body: Any case the latest changes to the code could be released on PyPi?

items.title: Option for further control on Tornado's Cache Control (incl. ETag)
items.body:
This is an extension of #101 .

Our use case is having `livereload` serve a `sphinx-server`  with `sphinx_autobuild`'s live reload watcher. We start the livereload server with `server = Server(watcher=sphinx_autobuild.LivereloadWatchdogWatcher())`, so that means that the web content is served by your `StaticFileHandler`, which extends Tornado's own.

Just like in #101 , the ETags generated by Tornado's StaticFileHandler do not change even when the underlying HTML has been altered ( as noted here : tornadoweb/tornado#892 ), which means the browser will use its cache and not request the updated content.

Thanks to your fix with [`7d0eb7e`](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/commit/7d0eb7e745c379a66158e6f05cfa7eeda56c0d44) , we can now see the updated content when **force-reloading** (so, ignoring the cache).

---

We would like to not have to force-reload without disabling the browser's cache ( notably for embedded browsers such as the ones that can be included in IDEs and text editors ).

In order to do this, we would like to implement changes to the `StaticFileHandler`, such as for example overriding Tornado's `RequestHandler.compute_etag` and `RequestHandler.set_extra_headers` if a certain flag is set.

If this functionality is okay with you, we will happily open a pull request for this. 🙂

items.title: AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'repr_str'
items.body:
While running `python3 setup.py test`, I got the following traceback.

```
======================================================================
ERROR: test_watch_file (tests.test_watcher.TestWatcher)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/tmp/autopkgtest.2Pi2SP/build.cBN/python-livereload-2.5.2/tests/test_watcher.py", line 66, in test_watch_file
    rv = watcher.examine()
  File "/tmp/autopkgtest.2Pi2SP/build.cBN/python-livereload-2.5.2/livereload/watcher.py", line 92, in examine
    func.repr_str, delay))
AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'repr_str'
```

The reason is that the test function add_count doesn't have its own repr_str defined.

items.title: Could you embed the images for download and pypi into README.rst?
items.body:
Hi,

In Debian, we are packaging your work in the source package python-livereload. The thing is, we have to maintain a patch that strips from the documentation the two images that are shipped by `README.rst` file, as hotlinking to external sites is a potential privacy breach for our users.

Could you embed into your project both of these images so that both images are shipped in the compiled documentation into Debian, and thus we don't break any privacy by having them and thus can drop our debian-specific patch?

Cheers!

items.title: [setup.py] Please add missing install_require dependency on pkg_resources
items.body:
Hi,

We realized in Debian that your python module's `setup.py` doesn't state that pkg_resources is required at installation by livereload while it's used in `handlers.py`.

Could you add it as a dependency in the `setup.py` file, please? :)

See https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=896399 or https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=896315 for more intel.

items.title: recursive glob for python 3.5+
items.body:
here's my custom watcher to enable [recursive glob](https://docs.python.org/3/library/glob.html#glob.glob) using `**` which was added in python 3.5+

```python
from livereload.watcher import Watcher

class CustomWatcher(Watcher):

    def is_glob_changed(self, path, ignore=None):
        for f in glob.glob(path, recursive=True):
            if self.is_file_changed(f, ignore):
                return True
        return False
```

```python
from livereload import Server
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)
app.debug = True

server = Server(app.wsgi_app, watcher=CustomWatcher())
server.watch("./**/*.j2")
server.serve()
```

items.body:

What would be the best way to explicitly reload the server from another thread? I already have a thread that triggers on some events (like a watcher) and I would like it to force reload on the running server. Is that possible? How?

For now, I am writing from that thread on a file and then I add a watcher to the server to watch that file as well, but that seems "dirty" to me and was wondering if there was another way to do it.

Thanks for your help. :blush:

items.title: Integrating livereload with flask
Cannot deal with a txt file
items.body:
Hi I want to start a server, watch a txt file which is being updated throughout the program. But I get always 404. Docs are pretty useless, please help!
Thanks in advance

```
import sys
import telnetlib
import os
import time
import _thread
from livereload import Server, shell


server = Server()

HOST = "192.168.42.16"
tn = telnetlib.Telnet(HOST)

date = time.strftime("%H:%M") + "_" + time.strftime("%d-%m-%Y")
filename = 'log.txt'#"log_" + date + ".txt"

logfile = open(filename, 'a')

def dataServer():
    server.watch(filename, delay=2)
    server.serve(port=8000, host='TSMacBookAir.local')

def dataLogger():
    print("log start")
    _thread.start_new_thread(dataServer,())
    try:
        while True:
            readings = tn.read_until(b"V")
            strToWrite = str(readings, 'utf-8')
            logfile.write(strToWrite + "\n")
            #print(strToWrite)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        pass
    logfile.close()
    sys.exit()

_thread.start_new_thread(dataLogger,())
```

items.title: Convert readthedocs link for their .org -> .io migration for hosted projects
items.body:
The link on the Github repo description needs updating for the RTD migration, as per [their blog post of the 27th April](https://blog.readthedocs.com/securing-subdomains/) ‘Securing subdomains’:

> Starting today, Read the Docs will start hosting projects from subdomains on the domain readthedocs.io, instead of on readthedocs.org. This change addresses some security concerns around site cookies while hosting user generated data on the same domain as our dashboard.

https://livereload.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ is where one now ends up

items.title: Fallback Content-Type should be application/octet-stream
items.body:
In [Tornado](https://github.com/tornadoweb/tornado/blob/master/tornado/web.py#L2589), the fallback Content-Type is `application/octet-stream` for any unknown types. While LiveReload does not alter that behavior in its [`StaticFileHandler` subclass](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/master/livereload/handlers.py#L150), it does use `text/html` [elsewhere](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/master/livereload/server.py#L132). When using LiveReload, the following file types are being returned with `Content-Type:text/html`:

| File Extension | Expected Content-Type | Acceptable Fallback | Actual |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `.woff2` | `font/woff2` | `application/octet-stream` | `text/html` |
| `.woff` | `font/woff` | `application/octet-stream` | `text/html` |
| `.ttf` | `font/ttf` | `application/octet-stream` | `text/html` |
| `.mustache` | `text/template` | `application/octet-stream` | `text/html` |
| `.json` | `application/json` | `application/octet-stream` | `text/html` |

I've included the expected content types above, but in all cases, modern browsers seem to behave as expected with `Content-Type:application/octet-stream` (see mkdocs/mkdocs#897). Therefore, it seems to me the fallback should be `application/octet-stream`.

I expected that LiveReload would just use whatever Tornado returned, and in fact with a a look at the code I can see `Content-Type:text/html` is only being set if no content type is already defined. But apparently something is awry.

items.title: Script specifies host and port which breaks reverse proxies
items.body:
https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/master/livereload/server.py#L224

If I use a reverse proxy with livereload, it uses the server's port, not the exposed port.  Why not just use "/livereload.js"?  This would at least make reverse proxies work, though it still wouldn't let you put the site behind a specific path.

items.title: Assign watch for subdirectory does not restart the server one changes in that subdirectory
items.body:
Have a simple flask app with a templates subdirectory. I use the following for my livereload file

``` python
from livereload import Server
from fhir_amp_tutorial import app

server = Server(app.wsgi_app)
server.watch('templates/', delay=2)
server.serve()
```

However when I change one of the template files, the server is not restarted. When I add in an alert, the alert gets triggered.

items.title: Optional -w WAIT parameter does not exist
items.body:
The documentation names a '-w WAIT' optional parameter, does this still exist?

> $ livereload --help
> usage: livereload [-h] [-p PORT] [-w WAIT] [directory]
> 
> Start a `livereload` server
> 
> positional arguments:
>  directory             Directory to watch for changes
> 
> optional arguments:
>  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
>  -p PORT, --port PORT  Port to run `livereload` server on
>  -w WAIT, --wait WAIT  Time delay before reloading

Running with this parameter does not work:

> livereload -w 530
> usage: livereload [-h] [--host HOST] [-p PORT] [directory]
> livereload: error: unrecognized arguments: -w

items.title: No support for static files during development in Django
items.body: If you pass the Server instance the django WSGI application; it does not automatically handle static files, which is a big issue during development.

items.title: Broken link in "Fork me on Github" ribbon at http://livereload.readthedocs.org
FakeWaiter: trigger tasks always
items.body:
I am using python-livereload for a `make watch` task, and would like to trigger
the `make scss` task always, without some browser having connected before.

This can be done by attaching some fake-Waiter like this:

```
class FakeWaiter:
    "A no-op waiter to trigger scss re-building always."
    def write_message(*args, **kwargs):
        pass

LiveReloadHandler.waiters.add(FakeWaiter)
```

I think this should be supported by default (by some option), or a `Waiter`
like this should be provided by python-livereload (in case the implementation
changes).

items.title: UTF-8 problem on Windows
items.body:
I had a problem with utf-8 encoded files on Windows while trying to use mkdocs. 
The solution is to modify `handlers.py` file by:

Adding:

```
        mimetypes.add_type("application/vnd.ms-fontobject", ".eot")
        mimetypes.add_type("application/x-font-ttf", ".ttc")
        mimetypes.add_type("application/x-font-ttf", ".ttf")
        mimetypes.add_type("font/opentype", ".otf")
        mimetypes.add_type("application/x-font-woff", ".woff")
```

  before 

```
        ﻿mime_type, encoding = mimetypes.guess_type(filepath)
```

Changing:

```
        ﻿if mime_type.startswith('text'):
            with open(filepath, 'r') as f:
```

  to

```
        ﻿if mime_type.startswith('text'):
            with open(filepath, 'r') as f:
```

items.title: livereload does nothing if no browser is watching
items.body:
We use livereload in http://getnikola.com to monitor site changes and trigger rebuilds.

When using `nikola auto -b` which calls livereload with `open_url=True` everything works normally.
However, when not using that, rebuilds are never triggered.

items.title: Don't try to browse fragments as whole URLs
items.body: When trying livereload with a page written in, say, Ember.JS, the reload causes the browser to try and browse to http://localhost:8000/#/some/path as if it were a whole URL, and does not properly distinguish the fragment from the URL...

items.title: Failure with current master
items.body:
I get this with the current git master. It works with `2.3.2`.

We may be doing something wrong, I'm not sure. Our code to replicate this can be found here:
https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/blob/master/mkdocs/serve.py#L11-L26

```
INFO    -  Building documentation... 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./.tox/livereload-dev/bin/mkdocs", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('mkdocs==0.13.0.dev0', 'console_scripts', 'mkdocs')()
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/click/core.py", line 664, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/click/core.py", line 644, in main
    rv = self.invoke(ctx)
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/click/core.py", line 991, in invoke
    return _process_result(sub_ctx.command.invoke(sub_ctx))
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/click/core.py", line 837, in invoke
    return ctx.invoke(self.callback, **ctx.params)
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/click/core.py", line 464, in invoke
    return callback(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mkdocs/cli.py", line 75, in serve_command
    livereload=livereload,
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mkdocs/serve.py", line 83, in serve
    _livereload(host, port, config, builder, tempdir)
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mkdocs/serve.py", line 20, in _livereload
    server.watch(config['docs_dir'], builder)
  File "/home/dougalmatthews/Code/python/mkdocs/.tox/livereload-dev/lib/python2.7/site-packages/livereload/server.py", line 198, in watch
    self.watcher.watch(filepath, func, delay)
TypeError: unbound method watch() must be called with Watcher instance as first argument (got str instance instead)
```

To replicate this locally with Tox, you need the small additions I made here to the tox config here: https://github.com/d0ugal/mkdocs/tree/tox-additions then run:

```
tox -e livereload-dev
./.tox/livereload-dev/bin/mkdocs serve
```

That should start serving the MkDocs documentation on locahost:8000. To compare with a working version run:

```
tox -e py34-unittests
./.tox/py34-unittests/bin/mkdocs serve
```

Thanks!

```
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "/var/tmp/portage/dev-python/livereload-2.3.2/work/livereload-2.3.2/tests/test_watcher.py", line 60, in test_watch_glob
    assert watcher.examine() is None
AssertionError
```

Are these failures anything to be concerned about or are they ignorable?  If they are of concern I can attempt a patch; otherwise, I'll simply ignore these tests.

items.title: Broken browser caching?
items.body:
I used livereload 2.3.2 on my Sphinx documentation successfully.  Then I pip installed git master.  Now reloading doesn't work:
1. I load a page in the browser, http://localhost:5500/foo.html
2. I edit foo.rst
3. I see the browser page reload
4. I still see the old content
5. I verify that the HTML file on disk has new content
6. I hit Ctrl-R to reload the browser tab manually
7. I still see the old content

I used Chromium's developer tools to look at the HTTP requests: livereload is responding with a 304 Not Modified to the request, which includes If-Modified-Since and If-None-Match headers.

I can see the new content if I use Ctrl+Shift+R to reload.  I see HTTP responses with Server: TornadoServer/4.0.2 and Etag: "586cf5820eb5f1633c93a490820935b6" which doesn't change, even when the HTML file changes.

items.title: Wishlist: use INotifyWatcher() by default if it is available
items.body: The title says it all: it'd be nice if Server() without an explicit watcher argument could determine the best watcher that's supported on your system.

items.title: Wishlist: recursive watching for a file pattern
items.body:
I want to run a command whenever a filename matching a particular glob pattern (`*.rst`) changes in a directory tree.

I can watch the directory tree recursively with `server.watch('directory/')`, but this triggers for other kinds of files as well.

I can watch for a glob pattern (`*.rst`), but this doesn't support recursive globbing ([yet](https://docs.python.org/dev/whatsnew/3.5.html#glob)).

Possible solutions:
- implement `'**/*.rst'`-style globbing (perhaps backport the feature from Python 3.5?)
- add a `filter` argument so I could say `server.watch('.', filter=lambda fn: fn.endswith('.rst'), func='make html')`

Note that a solution to manually use an external library for file globbing, like the one [suggested in the manual](http://livereload.readthedocs.org/en/latest/#server-watch), is unsuitable because it would not pick up newly-created files or subdirectories.

items.title: Possible TypeError: unorderable types: str() > int() on Python 3
items.body:
I noticed this while reading through the source code of [examine](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/efd376b6e0ae7af302d69081605ce335a9f0692b/livereload/watcher.py#L57-L65) (BTW the source code is very clean and elegant!):

``` python
        delays = set()
        for path in self._tasks:
            if self.is_changed(path):
                func, delay = self._tasks[path]
                func and func()
                delays.add(delay)

        if delays:
            delay = max(delays)
```

If you have a task with `delay='forever'`, as well as a task with a numerical delay, and if they trigger simultaneously, this code will end up evaluating `max(set([0, 'forever']))` which fails on Python 3:

``` python
>>> max(set([0, 'forever']))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unorderable types: str() > int()
```

items.title: Ignore open_url=True when live-reloading the server
items.body:
I've a `live.py` that looks like this:

``` python
from livereload import Server

server = Server()
# no recursive globbing on Python 2 :(
for pattern in '*.rst', '*/*.rst':
    server.watch(pattern, 'make html')
server.serve(root='_build/html', open_url=True)
```

Every time I make a change to it, I see

>  [I 150408 13:13:54 autoreload:195] live.py modified; restarting server

on the console, and then I get a new browser tab.

I _like_ that livereload reloads its own configuration every time the script changes, but would it be possible to ignore open_url when the reload happens?

items.title: Document how to use livereload
items.body:
Hello!

I came here from http://serialized.net/2013/01/live-sphinx-documentation-preview/ and got all confused: the blog post talks about Guardfiles, which is not mentioned once in http://livereload.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ or in the repository.

Trawling through the issues makes me think python-livereload used a Guardfile at some point, and then stopped.  Instead I now have to write a Python script with the right incantations.  Fair enough, but it'd be nice if the documentation had a small note about this, with an example describing how to convert a Guardfile like the one mentioned in the above blog post into a script.

items.title: No CLI for Windows?
items.body:
Hi, the documentation reads, that there is a CLI:

```
$ livereload --help
usage: livereload [-h] [-p PORT] [directory]
```

 At least for Windows none is available. the installation worked without errors. Am I doing anything wrong? Thank you.

items.title: make open_url timeout configurable
items.body:
Currently it is just set to 5, but I think it would make sense to make it configurable, using e.g. a open_url_timeout parameter.

If you think it is a good idea, should I suggest a pull request?

items.title: Log to 'livereload' logger name instead of root logger
items.body:
Hi, instead of logging to the rootLogger via 

```
import logging
logging.info('stuff')
```

I think it would be better to use a named logger via:

```
import logging
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
logger.info('stuff')
```

This way gives the user more granular control and won't accidentally interfere with the user's settings if they had already set up their root logger.  I'd be happy to provide a PR if you agree.

items.title: no reload for the wsgi app?
items.body: i just skimmed the source, how is code-change in the wsgi app handled?

items.title: Server.serve ignores root argument
items.body:
e.g.

``` python
server.serve(root=config['static_dir'])
# app will be served out of CWD regardless of the value of root
```

Looks like it has to do with `Server.root` [being initialized](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/master/livereload/server.py#L146) to `None`, and when `serve` is called, the parameter `root` is [ignored](https://github.com/lepture/python-livereload/blob/master/livereload/server.py#L212).
Not sure if this is the intended behavior. Thanks!

items.title: Protocol version 8 and 9, wowsie!
items.body:
Hey! I've just learned that python-livereload claims support of LiveReload  protocols version 8 and 9.

Any chance you can shed some light on those? I confess I wouldn't mind supporting them as well. Also, can I borrow your time machine for just a few minutes?

items.title: Add grace_period just like guard-livereload
items.body: I'm using this in a django application to watch py files, but since there's no grace_period option to wait a specified number of seconds before restarting, the browser refreshes before the server (started as `./manage.py runserver`) has restarted.

items.title: Release Python 3 support
items.body: It would be great to have a release with Python 3 support.

items.title: Watch files without a connected browser
items.body:
It seems like python-livereload only starts to watch files for changes if there's a browser connected.

I want to use python-livereload with a generic `watch` task to build scss files automatically, and there does not have to be a browser connected necessarily.

(issue #63 might be related)

items.title: (Almost) Realtime reload in browser
items.body:
Is there any way to make browser reload in realtime like we have in sublime? I experience a few second (3-5) longer than sublime.
PS: I use vim

items.title: Use different ports for app (http) and livereload (websocket)
items.body:
It looks like the websocket request to `/livereload`, prevents any further AJAX requests from being possible.

I've noticed this with Django's Debug Toolbar (a separate app), where the requests to `/__debug__/render_panel/?store_id...` are not being sent from Firefox and/or logged from python-livereload.

I guess that using a dedicated port for the websocket connection would help here.

items.title: Watch files without triggering a livereload
items.body:
I would like to watch `.scss` files, and trigger a function for them, but want to only trigger a livereload for changed `.css` files (please notice the new `livereload=False` keyword argument):

```
for filepath in formic.FileSet(include="./htdocs/static/**/*.css"):
    server.watch(filepath)
for filepath in formic.FileSet(include="./htdocs/static/scss/*.scss"):
    server.watch(filepath, 'make sass', livereload=False)
```

This would allow to trigger the livereload only when the .css file changes (i.e. there is no compilation error).

items.title: The shell() function does not treat correctly a single argument if it contains the whitespace character
items.body:
The shell() function works very well as long as the command line parameters do not contain the space character ' ', but if I need a command parameter that has a space character, the current implementation treats it as 2 separate parameters.

Python's subprocess.Popen interface works amazingly well because it does not accept a space separated string as the command parameters, but it uses a list instead.
My proposal is to have the shell() function accept both a string or a list (or any other iterable), and if it is a string, then it splits it as it does now, else it passes the command as it is to Popen.

items.title: Error when opening a directory name without trailing slash
items.body:
This is reported as getnikola/nikola#1180 but basically, if there is a `foo/index.html` and you open `foo` then this will happen:

```
    self._when_complete(method(*self.path_args, **self.path_kwargs),
  File "/home/ralsina/.virtualenvs/nikola/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/livereload/handlers.py", line 181, in get
    with open(filepath, 'r') as f:
IOError: [Errno 21] Is a directory: u'/home/ralsina/Desktop/proyectos/nikola/master/foo/output/galleries/demo/foo'
```

items.title: Re-instate CLI functionality
items.body:
I have been using `liverload@1.0.0` from the command line for a while without any problems. Recently, I was setting up a coworker and we noticed that as of `2.0.0`, this functionality is gone.

There doesn't seem to be any documented reason (issue or changelog) why it was removed. Can you explain the reason and possibly put the functionality back in?

items.title: Support for extended / recursive globs
items.body:
I have just proposed it for pyinotify already:
https://github.com/seb-m/pyinotify/issues/60

python-livereload would need to understand the same extended globs and/or could expand them before adding the watches (and pass do_glob=False).

I believe it's a very useful feature to have something like **.py etc.

See http://www.aviser.asia/formic/doc/

items.title: Livereload might interfere with server restart (when watching for application .py files)
items.body:
I have noticed that the application automatically gets restarted, if a .py file changes, but it does not trigger a browser reload.

When adding the .py files as tasks, this will trigger a browser reload, but it results in a HTTP error, because the server is restarting when the reload is triggered.

What is the proposed way to get livereloading in this case?

Shouldn't any reloads get triggered after a server restart?

items.title: Use/allow another name for Guardfile
items.body:
The `Guardfile` filename clashes with what guard is using, and creates confusion.

It would be nice, if you could specify an alternate filename.

I realized that python-livereload is going in another direction currently, but as long as a file is provided to load/add tasks dynamically, this is an issue.

items.title: A livereload server for wsgi
items.body:
Now, livereload will be a library rather than an application. in version: 2.0.0

``` python
from livereload import Server

server = Server(wsgi_app)
# run a shell command
server.watch('static/*.stylus', 'make static')
# run a function
server.watch('foo.txt', lambda: print('foo'))
server.serve()
```

With this snippet it will serve an wsgi application, and it will insert the livereload.js script into the response body.

items.title: hash.update() fails with Python3
items.body:
I'm getting this error using Python3.3:

```
$ livereload
Serving path . on 127.0.0.1:35729
[I 130920 13:56:21 server:105] Browser Connected: http://localhost:35729/
[I 130920 13:56:21 server:112] No Guardfile
[I 130920 13:56:21 task:54] Add task: /tmp/demosite/output
[I 130920 13:56:21 server:116] Start watching changes
[E 130920 13:56:24 web:1228] Uncaught exception GET / (127.0.0.1)
    HTTPRequest(protocol='http', host='localhost:35729', method='GET', uri='/', version='HTTP/1.1', remote_ip='127.0.0.1', headers={'Accept-Language': 'es-ar,es;q=0.8,en-us;q=0.5,en;q=0.3', 'Cache-Control': 'max-age=0', 'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:24.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/24.0', 'Host': 'localhost:35729', 'Connection': 'keep-alive', 'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip, deflate', 'Cookie': '__atuvc=190%7C37%2C308%7C38', 'If-None-Match': '"f564fb0397076cb4ea165b7847bf127bf7d581e3"', 'Accept': 'text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8'})
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/home/humitos/.virtualenvs/nikola-dev-py3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/tornado/web.py", line 1141, in _when_complete
        callback()
      File "/home/humitos/.virtualenvs/nikola-dev-py3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/tornado/web.py", line 1162, in _execute_method
        self._when_complete(method(*self.path_args, **self.path_kwargs),
      File "/home/humitos/.virtualenvs/nikola-dev-py3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/livereload/server.py", line 131, in get
        self.read_path(abspath)
      File "/home/humitos/.virtualenvs/nikola-dev-py3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/livereload/server.py", line 167, in read_path
        hasher.update(data)
    TypeError: Unicode-objects must be encoded before hashing
[E 130920 13:56:24 web:1635] 500 GET / (127.0.0.1) 5.74ms
[I 130920 13:56:24 web:1635] 200 GET /favicon.ico (127.0.0.1) 4.69ms
^CShutting down...
```

I'm not sure if this is a good fix, but it solves the issue:

```
--- server.py.bak   2013-09-20 13:31:09.552436660 -0300
+++ server.py   2013-09-20 13:31:12.872436657 -0300
@@ -164,6 +164,8 @@
                 self.write(data)

             hasher = hashlib.sha1()
+            if isinstance(data, str):
+                data = data.encode('utf8')
             hasher.update(data)
             self.set_header('Etag', '"%s"' % hasher.hexdigest())
             return
```

I'm using `livereload==1.0.1`

Issue copied from here: https://github.com/getnikola/nikola/issues/736

items.title: Add support for compiling SASS stylesheets
items.body:
As I see that there is support for compiling LESS stylesheet, it would be great if there was integrated support for compiling SASS stylesheets as well in compiler.py

A function that compiles SASS stylesheets can be found here:

http://pastebin.com/6a0d2AKT

items.title: pyinotify does not work if the file inode changes (i.e. when the original file is deleted and moved over)
items.body:
When creating a Guardfile I have noted that if I add a task like this:

Task.add('my_directory')

everything works fine, but if I add a task like this:

Task.add('my_file.html')

when I modify the my_file.html file the livereload event does not trigger.

When looking for a solution I have tried to force the HAS_PYINOTIFY variable to False in the task.py file, and when disabling pyinotify everything works correctly, which means the problem lies somewhere either in the pyinotify integration, or in pyinotify itself, or I have some settings that prevent inotify to notify changes to single files.

I am using Fedora 19 x86_64 with kernel 3.10.10-200.fc19.x86_64 and pyinotify version 0.9.4

items.title: CoffeeScript compiler not working correctly + fix
items.body:
The coffee function in compiler.py does not work correctly because it always compiles the file with the contents it had at the moment of the first function invocation, which results in the same output being generated regardless of the modifications made to the source file.

I have fixed the problem by creating a coffee function like this:

http://pastebin.com/FrfYjJAb

Can you integrate my solution (or at least a working coffeescript compiler) into python-livereload please?

items.title: livereload doesn't detect file creation
items.body:
Hi, I am using livereload to auto-rebuild a site from a static site generator, and it works GREAT! However, it seems not to be picking up file creation.

After the file is created, if I "touch" it, it's picked up and triggers a rebuild.

To reproduce:

In one terminal:

```
mkdir /mp/foo
cd /tmp/foo
livereload -b
```

In a second terminal:

```
cd /tmp/foo
touch bar [triggers no refresh]
touch bar [triggers refresh]
```

items.title: Can't handle PNG file

Injection must be performed in case of text/html only.

insta-infinite loop

items.title: infinity refresh
LiveReload Cannot connect to LiveReload server
items.body:
livereload  
启动后 用chrome livereload 插件 点击enable 出现:
*\* LiveReload Cannot connect to LiveReload server:
ws://127.0.0.1:35729/websocket

后台log  
*_Start service at  127.0.0.1:35729
*_[W 120820 00:21:18 web:1447] 404 GET /websocket (127.0.0.1) 0.39ms

items.title: 修改后浏览器会一直刷新？
items.body:
我的 Guardfile

https://gist.github.com/3143786

修改 `static/css/style.less` 之后就会一直返回：

`[Timestamp] Reload 1 waiters
    Changed ['static/css/style.less']`

然后浏览器(Chromium 20)就不停刷新了(中途没有修改动作)，但是用 liveload.js 不是一直刷新的吧？只是一直请求到有修改为止。

items.title: markdown preview
items.body:
```
$ livereload a.md
```
